metadata.title: Sharp Bounds for Generalized Uniformity Testing
metadata.author: Ilias Diakonikolas, Daniel M. Kane, Alistair Stewart
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We study the problem of generalized uniformity testing of a discrete probability distribution: Given samples from a probability distribution p over an unknown size discrete domain Ω, we want to distinguish, with probability at least 2/3, between the case that p is uniform on some subset of Ω versus -far, in total variation distance, from any such uniform distribution. We establish tight bounds on the sample complexity of generalized uniformity testing. In more detail, we present a computationally efficient tester whose sample complexity is optimal, within constant factors, and a matching worst-case information-theoretic lower bound. Specifically, we show that the sample complexity of generalized uniformity testing is Θ 1/( 4/3 p 3) + 1/( 2 p 2) .

highlights: Consider the following statistical task: Given independent samples from a distribution over an unknown size discrete domain Ω, determine whether it is uniform on some subset of the domain versus significantly different from any such uniform distribution
An immediate open question arising from the work of [BC17] is to precisely characterize the sample complexity of generalized uniformity testing
Before we describe our algorithm, we summarize a few preliminary results on estimating the power sums Fr(p) = i∈Ω |pi|r of an unknown distribution p

Suppose that we have such families D and D , but that there is an algorithm A that distinguishes between a distribution p being uniform and being -far from uniform when p 2 = Θ(n−1/2) and p 3 = Θ(n−2/3) in m = o(n2/3/ 4/3) samples

summary: Consider the following statistical task: Given independent samples from a distribution over an unknown size discrete domain Ω, determine whether it is uniform on some subset of the domain versus significantly different from any such uniform distribution.

There is an algorithm with the following performance guarantee: Given sample access to an arbitrary distribution p over an unknown size discrete domain Ω and a parameter 0 < < 1, the algorithm uses O 1/( 4/3 p 3) + 1/( 2 p 2) independent samples from p in expectation, and distinguishes between the case p ∈ CU versus dTV (p, CU ) ≥ with probability at least 2/3.
There exists an algorithm that given sample access to a distribution p, a positive integer r and a 1 > δ > 0, computes a value γr so that with probability at least 19/20 we have that

There exists an algorithm that given sample access to a distribution p, and n, > 0 with ≥ n−1/4 takes an expected O(n2/3/ 4/3) samples from p and distinguishes with probability at least 9/10 between the cases: (i) p is the uniform distribution on a domain of size Θ(n).
1: procedure LARGE-EPS-TESTER(p, n, ) input: Sample access to arbitrary distribution p on unknown discrete domain Ω and n, > 0 and

There exists an algorithm that given sample access to a distribution p, and n, > 0 with ≤ n−1/4 takes an expected O(n1/2/ 2) samples from p and distinguishes with probability at least 9/10 between the cases: (i) p is the uniform distribution on a domain of size Θ(n), and p is -far from any uniform distribution.
1: procedure GENERALIZED-UNIFORMITY-TESTER(p, ) input: Sample access to arbitrary distribution p on unknown discrete domain Ω and n > 0.

Suppose that we have such families D and D , but that there is an algorithm A that distinguishes between a distribution p being uniform and being -far from uniform when p 2 = Θ(n−1/2) and p 3 = Θ(n−2/3) in m = o(n2/3/ 4/3) samples.

The obvious research question is to understand the sample complexity of testing more general symmetric properties for the regime where the domain of the underlying distributions is discrete but unknown.
Is it possible to obtain sub-learning sample complexities for these problems? And what is the optimal sample complexity for each of these tasks?
headline: We study the problem of generalized uniformity testing of a discrete probability distribution: Given samples from a probability distribution p over an unknown size discrete domain Ω, we want to distinguish, with probability at least 2/3, between the case that p is uniform on some subset of Ω versus -far, in total variation distance, from any such uniform distribution
